The splattering of raindrops was echoing through the rustic chambers of the cathedral. Damp, cool air passed over your skin, and despite the mail you wear, managed to send a shiver coursing through your entire body. The sky had turned dark and vile, as if the lord himself was trying to signify a bad omen. 


"...and thus in the name of the Father his Son and the Holy Spirit, do you vow to uphold your piety and rule with the value of justice?"


"I do."


"Then I, Louis I, son of Charles I of Hungary, representative and prince-elector of the house of Anjou, do hereby declare you the king of the romans. May the whole of christendom prosper under your reign."


Golden torchlight was glistening off the plates attached to his mail. You had awaited this day, this exact moment for a very long time...all that’s left now is-


A guard dressed from head-to-toe in heavy plate mail rushes into the chamber, distracting you from your train of thought. He bears the crest of the house of Wittelsbatch on his armour. 


"What is the meaning of this? You dare to interfere with the ceremony?" says a commanding voice.


"I beg your pardon mein Herr," sayed the guard as he bows down. "However, it is of utmost importance that these premises be vacated. The army of the imperial cities has breached our defenses."

The streets of the bustling city of Prague had gone silent. Once upon a time, filled to the brim with merchants, tradesfolk and peasants, it now looks plain and deserted. The chill, cool air of the autumn weather passed through the city, as trees with yellowed leaves swayed gently in the breeze. Then, the grand city gates opened and in stepped a huge army. Footmen marched down the streets towards the Prague castle, being directed by a mounted man in dark steel plate, a knight. 


You clearly saw the approaching army through the fortifications. It’s a good thing that the alarm was sounded before hand. All you hoped for was that the people remain safe in their houses. 


The army came to a halt just before entering ballista range. The steel plate knight rode forward along with three heavily armoured soldiers on horse back, one of them carrying a white flag. You signaled the archers to be at ease. It was a dishonour to strike down an escort wishing to parley. The 4-man escort stopped short of hearing range at the foot of the castle.


"Greetings to the great emperor Charles, I am Ansel, the representative of the free cities and general of the coup. It is with deep remorse that things have come to this mein Herr, however I'm sure after violating the agreement we had settled upon this was a given."


"Herr Ansel of Millvesko. The perpetrator behind this whole ordeal. I'm glad to have met you here in person before I ordered your village to be run to the ground for treason!"


"Treason? What treason do you speak of mein Herr? We were never bound to your lordship, you agreed to grant us our freedom in exchange for alliance, military help and an annual tithe, and this is how you honour our agreement?! By selling us off to your subjects as mere slaves? Have you no honour Holy Roman Emperor, or has your worth fallen to those of con-men and scoundrel bandits?!"


"How dare you defile the name of your emperor!" shouts Wenceslas from behind. "You are going to apologize and repent for your actions, otherwise face the siniste-"


"Calm down son, we aren't a pack of barbarians. Things can still be settled in a diplomatic fashion, could we come to terms with negotiations herr Ansel? We could give you entry to the royal garden nearby to discuss."


"Agreed, mein Herr. I consider it foolish to negotiate for that which is rightfully mine; but it's better to save the bloodshed for another day. However, each of us will only bring along 3 guards."

“A fair proposal, Herr Ansel, we shall continue this conversation at the royal gardens. God be with you,” you say and prepare to gather your escort. 


“May God be with you too mein Herr, you’ll surely need luck and fortune,” Ansel begins to speak something but then stops himself. After a few moments he speaks,”I know the true reason behind your actions mein Herr...” he says while staring directly at Wenceslas,”and I would advice you as your subject and well-wisher to agree to this negotiations; or face sinister ramifications in lack of thereof.”




 

Beads of sweat begin to roll down your forehead. You close your eyes for a moment and think to yourself, making an attempt to call your nerves. Opening your eyes, you feel an instant of clearness, taking a long hard look at Wenceslas.




“I sincerely hope you see the light mein Herr, this negotiation will be beneficial to us both.” Ansel, along with three of his escorts, gallops towards the entrance of the fort. You walk through the fortifications, down the wooden stairway and look up to the cathedral in the main courtyard. “In the name of the Father, his Son and the Holy Spirit amen.” 




 

It’s a good thing you ordered the renovation of the castle. It’s been around for over 400 years now and hasn’t been once captured. The symbol of greatness of the kingdom of Bohemia no doubt. Various statues of the saints are constructed around the basalt platform. Their colour as white as the snow during the peak of winter. Decorative  pillars with little criss crosses lead all the way up to the towering rooftop. On top of which sits a miniature platform bearing the cross, made from pure silver mined in the bowels of the mountains near Skalitz. Highest structure of entirety of Prague. This reminded you of a verse by a bard you heard the other day...




 

“The great city of Prague, mighty with it’s legacy,


Worthy of a monologue, cause of strife and jealousy!


The strikes of hammer at forges, the pulls of carriages and horses,


Guided by King Charles, they’re destined for a legacy!”




 

The thought brought forth a sense of pride in your mind and a feeling of jubilance to your heart. “The lord has selected me and deemed me worthy enough to be where I am today. I will not let him down. It’s his and my will that this kingdom prosper under my reign. I only hope that my son follows this path...”




 

You turned to Wenceslas who was following you along with two of your best soldiers. 




 

“Son, I have gone through tests of fire and steel, of both the mind and body all in order to make give you the power you rightfully deserve. I’ve given Sigismund power over Hungary and you are my rightful heir to the throne. My obligations as your father are over, it’s now up to the both of you to work together an-“




 

“Father, father, why do you fear? Me and little sigi would surely be competent. We’ll bring Bohemia to a new legacy, following your footsteps.”




 

You turned around facing Wenceslas eye to eye,”Just remember one thing son, always remember this...

You walk down the path and enter the royal gardens along with your escort. The trees are mostly bare, containing a few yellowed leaves that gently sway in the thin cool breeze. For a split second, you’re lost in the lush, green atmosphere around you. 


 

Your men, all equipped with great swords, form a comb around you as you move forward and take a seat at the wooden table in the centre. Ansel and his men stand outside the locked gate and you signal the guards to open it for them. Ansel’s men carry halbreds and stand behind him. Without a word he takes a seat at the table, his expression completely unreadable. 


 

“You look young for your age Herr Ansel.” 


“My age, or my background isn’t of any concern to the current matters at hand mein Herr,” he says in a flat, emotionless voice. “I know what you want, and I’ll give you my word for the vote if you agree to my terms.”


“And what are these terms you speak of?”


“Total Sovereignty to the free cities, along with a population of tradesmen, farmers and blacksmiths for each city and a fee for violation of the contract agreed upon.”


“Have you forgotten all that I have done for you and your people? From the formation of the walls, to the establishment of the golden constitu-”


“I am aware of the legacy you’ve set, great king Charles. I beg your pardon for revealing this fact to you, but legend or stickpicker, there are consequences for all when-”


You stand up from your seat, placing your hands forcefully on the table.


“I am the rightful owner of the cities! It is I who was the founder of them, and I don’t care of the views of some imbecile prodigy noble who knows absolutely nothing about feudalism!”


 

Everything is silent for a few moments which feel like forever. You know the reason for your actions, it’s the only efficient way to secure the power your son rightfully deserves. This fool before you has no choice in the hand, the large army behind him is nothing but a grandiose charade.


 

“Very well then mein Herr, I see that you need more time to comprehend this decision since you’re clearly unable to realize the implications of your actions,” says Ansel before getting up and heading towards the exit. 


 

“And what if it isn’t my wish to agree?”


 

“You’ll regret it.”

“What’s wrong Father?” you ask as you get up from your kneeling position. 


“Coup of the imperial cities, I though I was done with Ansel for good.”


“That bloody stick picker!  We should’ve ambushed him and filled his guts with arrows when he had the chance!”


Suddenly, the main doors of the cathedral are hit by a huge force. The entire structure shakes with the impact, you can feel the vibrations at your feet. The main doors are forced open and in steps a group of soldiers in a shield formation. 


“At arms! Everyone at arms!” Shouts your father. Your men quickly rush forward, the shield bearers stand ahead while the men equipped with pole arms stay in the second line, they’ll attempt to break the enemy formation and create an opening in their flank. 


 

“Wenceslas, take a group of five men and leave for Prague! There are horses at the back entrance!”


“But fath-”


You’re cut off by screams of fighting and clashing of swords and shields. Five fully armoured men form a circular formation  around you, their kite shields held high up. Quickly you make your way out to the back. You’re currently wearing a ceremonial dress with nothing but a long sword sheathed at your waist. Hefting the hilt, you draw your sword, making the telltale clink sound of drawing from a sheath, and hold it with both hands. As you step outside, the scene is one full of carnage and destruction. There are dead everywhere, with mangled bodies and blood and gore being spilled on the damp wet ground. Rain water washes the path mixing with the blood in the form of miniature crimson red streams.


 

Hoof beats are heard behind you, turning around you see a group of 3 enemy horsemen equipped with pole arms. As they rush towards you, your company is caught unawares. The point of the pole arm pierces through plate mail like knife through butter. 3 of your guards are incapacitated and unable to stand. The two remaining guards manage to land a blow on the horses and their riders fall down the ground. One of the riders fall and turn unconscious, the other two quickly get up and assume their stance with the pole arm. Your guards equipped with their great swords, spin them around in circular motion covering a huge distance and try to keep the riders away from you. One of the riders miraculously manage to side step the guards and heads towards you, but not before his pole arm is parried out of his hand. He quickly draws his long sword and faces you.


 

You try and remember all that you’ve learnt about sword fighting from Grandmaster Liechtenauer, the blade master and your combat tutor.

You’re standing out in a huge open field, the summer afternoon sun bright in the sky. 


“No, incorrect. That is not how you hold a sword. Place only your dominant hand on the grip, the other hand should grasp the pommel of the hilt. If you hold the grip with both hands the pommel will obstruct your wrists making manuvers difficult.”


“Okay better. Keep your feet planted on the ground and try to hold a balance. Now listen carefully because I hate repeating myself. “There are four basic stances of the long sword. Each of these stances are the positions you should be in during wielding  long sword. These stances provide their own advantages and disadvantages while engaged in combat.”       


The first stance is the ox.”


 

The grandmaster draws the weapon up and to the outside of his left flank. The sword lies in a horizontal position with the point towards the outside.


 

“The point is typically aimed at the opponent's face or throat. This position is especially useful for keeping the opponent away and controlling the distance between you and your opponent. There are also quite a lot of cutting manuveurs you could perform directly from this position.”

The second stance is the Plow.”


The grand master holds the sword at his waist level at an angle, the tip pointing out. “The point should aim at the opponent's chest or throat and the hilt should be held more off to the side in front of the hip joint. Depending on which leg leads in the the hip the pommel is in front changes. This is primarily a defensive stance, but is very useful for thrusting by simply taking a step forward and backward”

“The third stance is the fool”


 

The grandmaster lowers the point of the sword  towards the ground . “The long sword is held point down, the blade lying with the legs. You can keep either foot out. This is an active stance and is extremely useful in parrying and countering. Also if you hold the sword outward towards the flank of your dominant hand you could deliver a tremendously powerful blow.”

The fourth stance is the roof”


 

The grandmaster raises the longsword  up with the shoulders, the tip facing upwards. “This is a threatening offensive stance, that can be used to either deliver a powerful blow or feint and manoeuvre.”


 

“Certain stances are useful against other stances, your aim in a sword fight is out manoeuvring the opponent and potentially trying to control his sword. For this, you’ll have to predict your opponents next blow by observing his stance. You should try and be as random and unpredictable in your opponents eyes as possible in order to land a strike.” 


“Remember that the long sword is a part of your body, it’s light and very easily controlled due to it’s weight distribution. To demonstrate this,” the master keeps the wooden sword on the ground and draws the sword at his waist, with the tip of his finger he’s able to balance the entire sword. “The distribution of weight is equal. A sword, a mace and a war hammer have the exact same weight but the difference between them is the concentration of mass. Maces and war hammers concentrate mass at a single point, sacrificing control for power; but with a sword you’re able to control much better and strike and maneuver with ease.”


“This is easier understood in a spar, now assume your stance and strike at me.”
The grandmaster is in the roof stance. Which stance should you take.

You assume the roof stance, the same as your grandmaster. The grand master comes in for a cut but feints at the last moment, turning into the Plow stance and thrusting at your throat.


The roof stance left your throat wide open, and you’re unable to block or deflect the blow in time. The wooden tip hits your throat causing you to violently cough.


“Hmm, you’ve got a long way to go. But do not fret, sword fighting is an art that demands time and energy, in time you’ll become better.”
Your opponent is dressed in a padded gambeson and is thus lightly armoured. Assuming from his stance and balance he appears to be moderately skilled. He assumes the fool stance. What do you do?

You assume a Plow stance, keeping your blade in front of your opponent and being on the defensive. However, this was a mistake as your opponent gets enough time to power up his fool stance and strike you with a very hard blow. The tip of your blade is not enough for a static block to such a blow and the blow breaks through your guard, slicing your throat in the process.


A very sharp burning sensation overwhelms your senses, and the next thing you know your on the ground. Your struggling to breathe through but the blade of the opponent has cut open your wind pipe. You perish, slowly, due to asphyxiation.

You assume a roof stance and rush forward striking at your opponent. Your opponent raises up his sword, deflecting your blow to his right flank but the momentum of your strike pushes you forward. Quickly your opponent maneuvers his sword, directing it straight at your forehead. It drives straight through your head. There’s very sharp pain for an instant and then...darkness.

You assume the fool stance, the same as your opponent. Your opponent gets enough time to give you a hard blow from his stance, however you manage to easily deflect his blow to your left flank and simply place the blade’s tip in front of his forehead. The momentum of his strike drives his forehead through the tip of your blade, and he falls down dead.


Your guards manage to dispatch the remaining two due the superior reach of their great swords as compared to their long swords and immediately cover your left and right flanks. Maintaining the trio formation, you head up towards the closest carriage and quickly step inside. The guards commandeer the horses and you ride away.


As you look through the opening in the back, you see fire. The cathedral is on flames...a single drop of tear passes from your skin down your face. Your father is dead.

The return back to Prague is a gloomy one. Everyone is shocked and cannot believe your words. The great King Charles has been slain in battle, and his body is nowhere to be found. A few days later, news comes that Herr Ansel has formed and gained support of a large number of lords and nobles and is openly rebelling against the crown.


“How much bloody longer will it take them to see the light,” you mutter under your breath.


“Fear not about those treacherous scoundrels mein Herr,” says Edward your royal advisor. “They have been taken care of for good. As of now there are a lot more pressing issues that needs your utmost attention.”


“Go on Edward.”


“The death of king Charles has put forth a feeling of dread and despair among your noble subjects. They fear for their land and the safety of their villages. The lands have been strife with war and pillaging. Since your coronation mein Herr, a lot of the lords have lost their faith in the crown. There are even rumours spread on you...” Edward stops for a second, refraining from speaking any further.


“Go on, I’m listening.”


“Rumours that the new king Wenceslas is unworthy, that his father gave up his life for him being elected as the emperor...that all he does is sit idly on his throne and pursues the more...greater pleasures of life...”


“6 months, mere six months to my coronation and they accuse me of hedonism and idleness...doesn’t matter. Perhaps this is the influence of the great stick picker Ansel.”


“Indeed mein Herr, I assumed the same. With more than half of the kingdom embroiled in civil war, trade routes have been blockaded, farmlands barren...the kingdom has seen better days.”


“Call court tomorrow and send invitations to all the lords who still have faith in the crown, best to act on this now before it’s too late.”


“As you say so mein Herr, I’ll take my leave.” 


“God be with you.”


Henry nods and takes his leave. You stand up looking around the room, the white chambers of the corridor glisten in the dawn sunlight. So much has happened in these last 6 months since the death of your father. Your coronation, the splitting of the kingdom between your half-brothers, civil war...it’s all so very stressful. You thought that you would be a Just and great ruler like your father, instead all that’s happened is your wealth being distributed 4-ways and then your share being robbed by the coup. Father had the great idea of having a strong bloodline to keep our house as the rulers...little did he now the repercussions of doing so. You need to I still order and instilling order requires wealth and wealth has been next to impossible to come by. At times you fear for your life and sleep with a sword at your bed...other times, in order to alleviate the intense stressful environment you’ve made some...unwise decisions.


There’s a knock on the door. 


“May I come in mein Herr?”, says a melodious and beautiful feminine voice.


“Who’s there?”


“How mean of you mein Herr, you don’t even remember my name? Have you forgotten all the fun we had last time?” Says the voice as the door opens. In steps a beautiful maiden, dressed in an extremely revealing gown. ‘Isabella’ you recall her name, she was the Italian wench you met yesterday.


“But I forgive you, I’ve got a kind heart after all,” she says while holding her chest, “and I’ve even got a few of my acquaintances this time, they would love to have fun and pleasure you...”

“Of course, how could I refuse such fine comely ladies,” you say. “I have an idea too,” you say while walking towards the hallway. “Raphael! Bring us the best wine and cheese available!” You shout out to your servant.


“Keep it a bit low on the wine this time mein Herr. You tend to get a bit...out of hand...overdoing that.”


Is doing this the right choice? Being in luxury and plushness while the land below you is strife with war, death and carnage? Is this the right thing you’re doing? Was this the will of your father?  


“Will of my father. My father has left me with a curse and not a will. This kingdom, this kingdom is beyond all hopes of improvement. These actions are just a way of releasing a bit of stress, and this kingdom is beyond any hopes of improvement anyway. Might as well enjoy as much as I can before I’m overthrown.”


The next day, you fail to attend the court in time and decide to cancel it in the end. The lords and nobles are extremely furious. Many of them have made the arduous journey to the capital, all because they had some hope in you. They believed that you had the capabilities to end the strife and war. 


One of the nobles is extremely angry and demands to see you. Edward calms him down, and goes to check on you. He pushes aside the guards of your chambers, who demand that they have been ordered to not let anyone in, and opens the doors. What he’s greeted with is a sight involving tables of half eaten delicacies and broken wine glasses. You’re on the bed, along with three other maidens under the sheets sleeping soundly.


“They were right about you, you’re worthless ‘Wenceslas the idle’.” He mutters in disgust and closes the doors.


After Edward left renounced his duties and left, things started to fall apart. The civil war continued on. The few remaining nobles loyal to you beg you and plead you for your help; you however are busy in lavishly spending the treasury for your own pleasures. 


In order to commemorate the great wedding of you and your wife Isabella, you order that a recreation of the bible be made, which would include art of you and your wife drawn by the most famous artists of all time. 


“Charles IV, your father deemed the addition of text or images by men in the holy scriptures as heresy. By doing this action, you risk going against your own father mein He-“


“It’s an order” you tell the priest firmly. 


“Very well.” 


There was a huge controversy regarding this decision, the church and the clergy did not take this lightly. In the end, the book was never finished and upon your questioning you’re given excuses. You let the matter go though, since there’s a more pressing issue currently at hand.

“You’re telling me the royal treasury has diminished?”


“Yes mein Herr.”


“How did this happen?”


“Due to the ongoing civil war and...other factors; most of the lords have reduced to pay their annual  tithes to the crown. This year’s tithes were only payed by the townsfolk of Prague. The economy is very do-“


“Enough,” you say putting your hand up, tired of listening to his lecture on the economy of the kingdom. “What is the solution?”


The royal treasurer thinks for a few moments. “Well, mein Herr I know of one person who could provide aid to the crown in this dire circumstance. The Benedictine Abbey of Kladruby.” 


“The abbey of Kladruby? Do you jest with me? Or do you suggest that priests have the holy power from the lord himself to create gold out of nothing?”


Completely oblivious to your blatant heresy, he continues, “The abbey of Kladruby needs a favour from the crown, for which he would be willing to pay generously. You would get a better picture of the whole idea if you meet him in person mein Herr. Do I have the permission of presenting him in court tomorrow?”


No matter how dubious this seems, you currently have no alternatives. “Very well, you have my permission.”


Next day during court, the treasurer is accompanied by a man dressed in the robes of the parish. With a silver chain bearing the cross dangling down from his neck. 


“It’s an honour to meet you in person, great Wenceslas IV. You have my deepest regards and my respect for gracing me with your presence mein Herr.”


“The pleasure is likewise sir...”


“Lauffen, the name’s Lauffen mein mein Herr. I suggest we discuss matters with a bit more discretion.”


You nod and signal the guards to leave the chamber. Only the treasurer and Lauffen remain behind.


“I heard that you’re in need of some favour?”


“Ah I see, straight to business then. Have you heard of the Avignon Papacy mein Herr?”


“Group of heretics who claim to be the pope and live in France instead of Rome?”


“Group of influential heretics, and let’s just say as an abbot I would gain a lot of profit if they were supported. Profit that I would willingly share with my allies.”


The Avignon Papacy. A group of rebellious clergy men who separated themselves from Rome and settled in Avignon France claiming that the pope Bonafice was a heretic; and that they were the true pope of the Christendom. This had been an ongoing political issue during the time of your father’s reign. You remember seeing your father giving an eloquent speech to the clergy of Bohemia and reassuring them of his support in the true Pope. Though currently you’re short on options. You’ll surely be chastised for this action and the church might completely withdraw their support from you; but if this monetary issue isn’t resolved you’re not going to hold on to your power for long. Let’s just hope you could get some support from this impersonator pope in the future.


 

 

“Alright, you have my word. I will favour the pope of Avignon and publicly declare my support, in presence  of the clergy of my kingdom.”


“That’s all I need from you mein Herr, I’m sure both of us will gain a lot from this endeavour.”

Next day, you walk down the streets of Prague along with 40 men-at-arms. The state of the capital has been in better condition. The roads and are full of filth and beggars. Peasantry dresses barely in rags, and with bodies as thin as paper hurry along out of the path of the march. “God’s teeth the stench! Hope I get out of this filth as soon as possible.”


Soon you reach the major town square. This area is extremely busy with vendors and merchants peddling their goods on the street. You see the Abbot in the distance at a stage in the town square and head towards him, along with him is the Archbishop of Bohemia and a group of other clergy. They bow in your presence. 


“I’m here today to discuss with all of you the Abbot of Kladruby’s decision to support the pope of Avignon. My father, god rest his soul, was the man of legends. He was gifted and destined by our lord to guide us to legacy. However during his reign, he was blinded by pope Bonafice. Since he was a child, he was taught to have unconditional love and support to the pope regardless of one’s own personal expectations. That was a time of blind faith. Today however, we aren’t bound by this one sided belief; and I can say this with certainty that the current pope is undeserving of his post. I am not blinded with one-sided faith like my father was; and I believe that the true pope who follows the principles of piety and devotion is not pope Bonafice of Rome but the pope of Avignon. It would be for the benefit of this fiefdom, and for the Christendom if we accepted this fact.” The priests are surprised and shocked to hear this. One of them, begin to argue with you implying that going against the true Pope of Romewas heresy.


“Heresy? You dare to call your king a heretic?”


“The true pope and prophet of the lord is the pope of Rome mein Herr, or are you trying to imply that there is more than one pope? Why do you wish to instigate this into a schism?”


“Because I said so, this is my kingdom and I can side with whoever I want and please. I don’t need the advice of a loudmouth who does not know how to respect his king!”


“Honour? You speak or honour mein Herr? After all the sins you’ve committed?”


An eerie silence settles over the entire hall. 


“What do you mean?”


 

“Wenceslas the great, son of a legacy,                                                                                                                                          


Resolved to rule, and change our destiny.                                                                                                                                            


He came forth as promising, a noble just king,                                                                                                                                   


Little did we know, ‘bout this person hedonic!                                                                                                                           


Pleasure and plush, was his only desire,                                                                                                                                             


His subjects ill-treated, forced to retire!                                                                                                                                                   


O great Wenceslas! Great wise king!                                                                                                                                                    


Is it your wish, to be disgraced by this thing?                                                                                                                                    


Have you stooped so low, that for mere wealth,                                                                                                                              


You’ll be the prophet, of the devil himself?”


 

Upon hearing this you’re enraged. Feelings of anger, shame and guilt all come to your mind at full force. These are then replaced by sheer anger and hatred. You look directly in the eyes of the priest. 


“What is your name, treasonous perpetrator?”


“John of Pomuck.”


You immediately order your guards to arrest him. 


The archbishop steps forward, “This man right here, is a part of the parish. Putting him through any harm is an attack towards the lord himself!”


“I am the king of Bohemia and the elected king of the Romans. This is my kingdom and I have the right to do what I please. Drown this treasonous piece of scum in the Vlatva river. May everyone know the ramifications of going against the king!”


The guards wordlessly drag the priest towards the river. The parish and priests warn you once again but you do not budge. The guards proceed to violently beat the priest with whips, he begins to lose consciousness with the pain and strife. You grab his head by your hands and drown his face in the fast running river. He begins to writhe uncontrollably for a few moments, until he stops moving. You then dump his dead body in the river.


“You will regret this Wenceslas,” is all the archbishop says before silently ordering the remaining priests to follow him. The priests stare at you with bloodshot eyes of pure hatred that threaten to pierce your eyes.


Over the next few days, it becomes evident that you have lost all support from the church. You get a letter from Rome, the pope wishes to meet the king of all Romans personally, in order to discuss recent events. You, however ignored the letter and in a few months time you receive news that the prince-electors have renounced you as the king of Romans. The payment that you were promised by the abbot is never received. In fact you don’t hear from him ever again, he seems to have disappeared. After all these events, comes forth the moment that you had feared the most.

“The imperial cities army is huge mein Herr, we are very highly outnumbered, for each of our soldier there are 10 enemy soldiers,” says the general. 


Of course there would be, that bloody stick picker has managed to convince the whole of Bohemia against you! He might also have the support of the church behind him. At these odds, victory seems impossible. Maybe it would be better for you to give up now and surrender? No, no you’re never going to surrender to that scoundrel! These are your lands and you’re either going to fight for them or die trying! 


 

A group of four riders ride forward, each dressed from head-to-toe in a suit of plate mail. This seems very similar to a situation in the past...


“Herr Wenceslas! It’s a pleasure to meet you again, it seems that in your short reign you’ve gained quite a reputation for yourself.” 


“Shut up, you rebel stick picker! Begone from the lands and my castle that is rightfully mine!”


“Right fully yours you say? If you had ruled these lands which are rightfully yours then with even a little semblance of honour then we would not have been in this situation today! I’m giving you two options Wenceslas, surrender or die trying.”


Standing on the fortifications, you stare upwards towards the bright blue sky. It’s the time of summer. The beautiful green vistas are completely filled with soldiers. They number in the thousands. You stand absolutely no chance of victory in this war.


 

Thinking back to the choices you made, the mistakes you committed, only you have to be blamed for this. You still remember advice given by father...’to look before you leap’ which you completely failed to follow. You know, you very well know they whatever choice you make now will be irrelevant. The reign of the king Wenceslas IV has come to an end. Regardless, you make your choice...

“Set up and load the catapults and ballistas!” 


As soon as you give the command, Ansel turns around and gallops away with his three guards. The enemy army marches with formation, the entire earth shaking beneath your feet. 


“There’s a fault in the mechanism of the siege engines mein Herr!”


“What? How is that possible?”


“Lack of repair and upkeep.”


Cursing under your breath, you order all the archers towards the wall and fire volleys upon the enemies. This however does little to stop their momentum. It is not long before the enemies manage to infiltrate and scale the tower and your forced to engage them in hand to hand combat. 


 

A heavily armoured man in plate mail, manages to breach the formation around you and strikes at you. You manage to narrowly side step and draw your long sword. The enemy, seeing you equipped with a weapon paces himself and assumes the ox guard.


What do you do?

Instantly you perform the ox guard, hitting his sword and putting both of you in a bind. The clash of the two swords brought out silvers of sparks. The force of the clash causes sends a violent jolt of vibration coursing through your arm. Trying to remember your grandmaster’s advice on a bind, you feel your opponent is about to push downwards with the the strong of his sword. What do you do?

You try and put all your strength against your opponent and push hard, but your opponent had a head start and manages to overcome your sword pushing it away. With the sword out of his way, he takes advantage of the opening thrusting his blade straight through your forehead. The thrust stings, stings like a thousand hornets, and then you fall into darkness.

Realizing your opponents intentions, you quickly retract your blade out of the bind. Due to the momentum of his strike he rushes forward exposing his back to you. Seizing the opportunity, you thrust your blade through the bottom of his torso plate, right between the gap where the two plates meet together. Breaking through the chain mail rings and right through the gambeson with your sharpened blade, you drive your blade right to the other end. Your opponent falls down, bleeding profusely. He will dead in minutes.

The battle is gruelling  and bloody. The enemy army forced you inside the castle, and broke through your formation 4 times. Each time resulting in heavy casualties for your side. Still you continue to fight on screaming orders from the top of your voice. Eventually it’s just you, and 14 men-at-arms that remain standing. You’re currently inside the court hall, in formation making your last stand. 


“Men, it’s time. Time to prove how worthy and battle hardened you are! Yes we all are going to die today, but let us die with honour, so that we can regale tales and fables of our bravery in the taverns of the afterlife!”


Your men cheer, and laugh at your jest, their morale high. Sometimes, you think back to what you could’ve done to prevent this situation you’re in. The attraction to pleasure was too great for you, and overcame your mind completely. Now however, it’s too late to dwell on this matter.


As the doors burst open, you and your men stand at guard for the incoming barrage of soldiers.


“Halt! At ease!” Screams a voice. Of course, it’s the bloody stick picker. 


“I gave you a chance mein Herr. Gave you a chance to surrender, maybe I would’ve shown mercy on you and let you live. But your arrogance and pride was too deep for you to see the light. Look! Look around you, look at what you’ve done! Death and destruction in thousands! Did you not care for the lives of your soldiers? Loyal to you till their death? Was it really wise to battle with an army that outnumbered you in the thousands? Doesn’t matter now, you along with your men are going to perish here, inside your own castle and court. I still give you a chance. Surrender.”

You drop your sword and order your men to drop their weapons. The opponents instantly surge forward tackling your soldiers and one of them takes you down on the ground hard knocking you out.


As you come back to your senses, there’s a sharp searing pain in your head. Looking around you, you notice you’re in a dungeon and your hands are chained to the walls. Your weapons and armour have been taken away from you and all you have on is a plain white tunic. The room filled to the brim with nothing but pure darkness. Suddenly, you hear a shutter opening at the base of the metal door and tray of food and water is pushed through it.

“It doesn’t even matter now.” you think. Indeed it doesn’t. 


Giving up you simply close your eyes and wish for death to overcome you, and eventually, it does come but you don’t even notice it...

“They say that a man begins to lose his sense of thinking when his end his near, you are the living envisage of that, Wenceslas.”


For a moment, everything is still and nobody moves. The atmosphere is eerily silent, as if this was the calm before the storm...


“Attack! Leave no one alive!”


The enemy army rushes forward, you order a shield formation but it’s a vain attempt. The pike weapons easily thrust through the formation and breaches through towards you. The tip of the pike goes straight through your heart. 


Pain, trembling burning pain. You feel the force of life draining right through your body. Then dizziness, weakness, the sky...darkness...

“I apologize, Isa. There are far more important things to do at this moment. This fiefdom has begun to fall apart and if I don’t make a move now I fear it’ll become too late.”

Ah she’ll come around, she always does. You kind of like her child-like personality though, so you might keep this on for a bit more...


More importantly, tomorrow is the day that could likely decide the future of this fiefdom. These last 6 months have simply flew over, considering your coronation and distribution of your father’s wealth across you and your 3 other half-brothers. At least your glad that your half-brothers did not demand more and left Prague castle under your dominion as father had hoped. It would certainly be beneficial for you if you could get their support and convince them tomorrow against that great stick picker Ansel. 


Then comes the nobles of the nearby land who claim to be loyal to the crown. Most of them are embroiled in war with Ansel’s supporters, and all that they seek for is peace. If you could help them by providing military support, they certainly would favour you, but that doesn’t serve their wishes. Sometimes, you think that you could always try and sign a treaty of sorts with the imperial cities, that way the war would be purely diplomatic in nature. “Treaty with that stick picker and for what is rightfully mine?”  Then again, it could buy you a lot of time to set up and execute a good plan to rid yourself of them.


The lords who are neutral, seek to not get embroiled in the war and be left alone. You see their point and you aren’t a mad bloodthirsty ruler who wants all his subjects slaughtered. If you could sign a treaty and make this from a war into a war of words then they could be more inclined to support the crown. Then again, there could also be those who ideologically believe that the Imperial cities should be free...


As for the treasonous lords who support Ansel, you’ll have to try something different. They are not going to be as easily available for parley as the other two. Maybe you could personally travel and persuade them? But they could fight you on sight and not give you a chance to speak. If you’re somehow able to convince these lords, that’ll be a major setback to Ansel and his treacherous plans.


You could also try and ask little Sigi for help. Though he’s not “little” anymore. You’ve heard he’s doing very well after defeating those invading mongols at the border of Hungary. Even then you would owe him a favour, and owing favours to other monarchs isn’t something you’re too fond of. Who knows how much has changed after these years though, would he still be willing to support you? He didn’t even attend father’s funeral...


 

You sit on the bed in your chamber, and give out a very noticeable sigh. As you lie down and pull up the covers, you say a short prayer to the lord in your mind. If everything fails all you’ll have with you to rely upon is him after all, and that’s a possibility that you hope does not come true

A mirror, with borders of silver and a few gems embedded in it is facing you. The flawless reflecting surface sparkling in the morning sunlight entering through the slightly open windows opposite. You look at your reflection and run your hand across your face. There's a slight stubble at your chin and you do look a bit too much pale; but nevertheless as a monarch. Running your hand down the pure silk of your cloak, you take the silver cross hanging around in your palm in your hand making the sign of the cross. "Lord, I wish and ask you for only one thing. Let whatever happen today happen with a positive outcome."


A knock on the door, and two servants enter holding the crown in their hand. After affirming your permission, they place it over your head and give a deep bow.


"The guests have arrived mein Herr, Sir Edward is engaged in conversation with them." 


"How's their mood Heinrich?" you ask the servant adressing you.


"They are pretty satisfied with the hospitality provided, as you had ordered we served them the finest red wine and cheese in the castle. One of them even complimented on how the king held them in high regard. Sir Edward is currently engaged in conversation with the council."


"Good, very good. Entertain any and every need they have and tell them I will be with them shortly."


"Sir Edward wanted you to have this," he says while putting forward a sealed envelope. "He says it's of great importance."


Taking it from his hand, you dismiss the servants and using the letter opener break open the seal. 


"Mein Herr,


I have managed to convince our friendly lords to provide military and financial aid to our war against the imperial cities. They have agreed on the condition that the king guarantees them a 25% reduced tithes to the church and kingdom; claiming it to be the cost of raising a war party. However, Herr Zubrech has demanded a 50% reduction, which is a bit outrageous. However, he has the best archers in the realm, along with a very good number and quality of artillery. The decision is upto you mein Herr.


The lords preferring the path of neutrality, are stubborn and did not wish any part of the war. I promised them that their lands would come to no harm by providing a manpower; but they did not budge. I believe if you could give them your word, they wouuld agree; however Herr Divish of Talmberg refuses to budge and is also trying to convince our supporting lords against their decision.


Surprisingly, quite a few of the rebellious nobles attended the council; but refused to speak to anyone other than the king. Mein herr, they refused to lay their weapons down and to take a seat. I would advise a bit caution.


One of the messengers informed that your younger brother, king Sigismund of Hungary was due to arrive today too.


Do come at the earliest, mein Herr. There's a slow development of restlessness in the atmosphere."

Father had told you that he had changed and he no longer would have any personal affection for our house, but to this extent? Does he not have even a droplet of care for his family? 


After closing your eyes for a moment and taking a deep breath you recall memories of your childhood, and your little brother.  The day you taught him to ride a horse for the first time. Your innumerable sparring sessions with him as a child. Though younger and weaker, he outclassed you in agility and skill. You remember the day of his departure eight years ago, you missed him a lot since then.


Shaking your head to clear out these memories, you push open the doors. You'll have time for a deep conversation later. Now, you've got to focus on this.

You could reprimand him on this and make an example out of him to keep the other nobles in line. After all power is achieved through only willingness to serve. You could instead, reprimand him and put your own points forward; or at least try to convince the others to not follow his path.

After discussing a few more details on the location, number of troops, etc. you dismiss the council.


"That's it then Edward. In within the next month we shall strike at them in the dead of the night and eleminate those scoundrels for good."


"I agree mein Herr, if all goes according to plan we should be able to restore peace in these lands once again."

"From whom?"

"Send him in."

One of the guards beside you takes the envelope from his hand and breaks the seal, handing it to you.

I should be arriving within a day or two of this letter's arrival to you.


Sigismund."

"Give my regards to Sigi."


"Certainly."

The main doors to the dining hall open and in steps your little brother, Sigi. He's become as tall as you and has a much more mature stance than before. He's changed so much appearance-wise that you couldn't recognize him for a second.


"Ah! Brother, its a pleasure to meet you," you say as you stand and head towards him."


"Pleasure's all mine," he says, and takes a seat directly opposite to you on the table.

"So, having a bit trouble with that unruly bastard Ansel, aren't you?

"That bloody stick picker is going to atone for what he has done. I'll make sure of that."

"Sir Radzig?"

"Certainly. What about Ansel then?"


"I've planned with the other lords to launch an assault at the fort of Millvesko at night. He won't even know what hit him."


"Oh I'm sure he won't."


You continue to dine along with your brother reminiscing about the old days. It's good to meet him after all these years, the palace certainly feels like home after a long time.

A servant enters the room and bows,"I apologise for the intrusion, but there is an urgent message to be delivered."


"What is it Heinrich?"


"You've got a letter from Rome, mein Herr, from the Pope Benedict."


"Well hurry up and open it then."


"As you say, mein Herr."


"Respected King of the Romans,


I kindly request your presence at Rome at the earliest, pertaining to a very serious matter at hand. Kindly be there at the earliest."


"Seems like a very urgent summoning for you, brother."


"And at the wrong time too, at that. A month before the invasion. Can't help it. Heinrich, send a letter to the Pope apologising, and explaining the coup along with the reason it's of paramount importance that my presence should be in Bohemia. Also write that I would be there at the earliest."


"As you wish, mein herr. I'll send it instantly."


"That was the wisest decision you could've made."


"I certainly hope so, father has given the both of a lot of responsibilities."

"Alright then, do come visit anytime you feel like. These castle doors will always remain open for you.

Flags of various houses, along with the flag of Bohemia perched at the top fly high in the deep night sky.


"We're here mein Herr," says a noble riding beside you.


"Let's set up camp then. I trust you all know what to do?"


"Yes. Set up camp, dig trenches, place traps and pikes and position men hidden in the canopy."


"What about the artillery?"


Another noble rushes forward on horseback,"Hidden safe and sound among the leaves mein Herr."


"Don't forget to activate them when you receive the signal. The success of this assault completely depends on that."

"Everyone! Everyone here listen to me! Lend me your ears! We are here today, on an endeavour to make things right, to serve this great kingdom of Bohemia by ridding them of these scum, to fight for the greater good! I expect all of you, sons of this great kingdom to show them our might; and to show them the greatness of our motherland!"


"We fight, we capture, we conquer!


 For a better day, for a better tomorrow,


 We see, we plan, we conquer!


To find a way, to avoid bitter sorrow,


 

We cry, we die, we kill,


For a right cause, for a just cause,


We try, we sigh, we fill,


A grave, for a better tomorrow."


Upon hearing this, you and your men feel your chest swell with pride; pride for the great kingdom of Bohemia. For all she has given you all, for all that you owe her. This kingdom, these lands are yours. They belong to you and your men and you will be damned if you let anyone do any harm to them! It is the will of the lord himself that you came to be where you are today. The Will of the lord that you could form this army, and it certainly is the will of the lord that you should be victorious today. The night sky is filled with echoes of shouts and cheers.
